Hey @whhackersbr,

I see your point, but this **still** requires a browser 0-day, HackerOne bug or Slack bug. HackerOne has `X-Frame-Options` set to `DENY` on the page, so even if there was an XSS in Slack you would still need to get a user to visibly click "Connect to Slack" within the session of you exploiting the Slack XSS. This makes it very low impact and likelihood of exploitation.

Additionally, if you have an XSS in HackerOne or a browser 0-day, then I think there are much bigger problems :)

Thanks for thinking of HackerOne security!
-@asuka

Hey @asuka,

Thanks for your attention.
;-)

> (...) but this still requires a browser 0-day, HackerOne bug or Slack bug

Browser 0-days and HackerOne bug is just an example of a way to exploit, not mandatory.

Slack XSS is needed, but you can't trust in third-party security, then the premise of security is to believe that the third-party bug already exists and we need to protect our systems against it, regardless if the other team will fix it or not or if the bug exists right now or not (https://hackerone.com/reports/132104).

> (...) Additionally, if you have an XSS in HackerOne or a browser 0-day, then I think there are much bigger problems :)

I am talking about low/medium impact bugs that can have a ​significant delay to be fixed (a browser clickjacking 0-day would not be considered pri-0, I am almost sure, at least in Chrome, I worked with Chrome bugs in the past).

Of course,​ the damage is worst if you have a hight priority browser 0-day or a HackerOne XSS.

_________________________________________________________________________________

The following video is just to show a point, it is not even close to the best way to exploit the design issue:

 * https://youtu.be/xOOguEcho7c

###PoC Conclusions###

1) Slack have the power to create an insecure instance of HackerOne;
2) Victim can take days/weeks to click on "Connect with Slack", but the instance will be always insecure while open;

Making an analogy, not fixing this, is the same as a browser vendor not fixing a SOP bypass because they believe in the ​good faith of all sites on the web.

The SOP basic principle is "Website A needs to be completely isolated of website B, in a way that one can not harm the other" (just in theory, hahaha, in the real world nothing is easy). 

No, your bug has "nothing" to do with browser SOP, but you need to use the same principle when thinking about​ security, but you are allowing Slack to damage HackerOne in some way.

P.S.: Today you just have Slack integration enabled without needing HackerOne support.
If you implement more automatic integration flows in the future, the risk of the design issue will grow​ significantly.

Hi @whhackersbr,

Thanks for the additional information, but we will be standing with our decision to not fix this bug. The reason we've settled on this are that there is a dependency on a vulnerability that *does not exist* to exploit this vulnerability. We've spoken with our engineering team and are okay with leaving this bug as is.

Thanks for thinking of HackerOne security!
-@asuka

> (...) that there is a dependency on a vulnerability that does not exist to exploit this vulnerability

Which vulnerability does not exist?

Just to see if we are on the same page.

Another impact:

To change the user's email, an attacker with physical access to the device would need the user's password. To change the password, he would need the password too. But he can still install an "invisible spyware" through the `Slack Integration` because it doesn't require any additional authentication, and the integration process doesn't send any type of warning to the team via email or other means like "Slack was integrated with your HackerOne account". The "spyware" will be invisible and active almost forever​.

Hi @whhackersbr,

Thanks for all the effort you've put in to your PoCs and your clear attention to detail, but we've decided we will not be fixing this issue and there does not need to be further discussion on it for now. 

All of the attack vectors you describe require a vulnerability in Slack, or a browser. While I agree with you that this area of our application could be more hardened, it poses very minimal risk due to the low likelihood of exploitation (you have to have the XSS in Slack then socially engineer/clickjack a click on H1 without using an iframe i.e. no UI redressing).

Thanks for thinking of HackerOne security!
-@asuka
